currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion,

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time,
What is excessive screen time?

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
What is excessive screen time?

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending  time on screens might be a problem if you're using a device to escape from the things around you or if you are ignoring your family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding.

 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring thei family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and e

Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment.

 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. But screens can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Most jobs will require emailing
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Most jobs will require emailing, talkign or texting 
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Most jobs will require emailing, talkign or texting multiple times a day
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing chart multiple times a day
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult
American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities.

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every ho

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog.

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones.

currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes.

Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them.

  t's all a matter of balance.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of ba

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going t

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---
Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We

We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We just need to teach them how to

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We just need to teach them how to balance it

Computers and phones are here to stay. Many jobs will require emailing, talking or texting, entering data, observing charts and screens multiple times a day. It is an unescapable part of adult life. 

American adults need to worry less about our own screen time and more about letting children sit alone on screens all day. We need to let them enjoy the company of their friends online, talk to them about the huge amount of bullying and meanness in the virtual world too. And we need to talk to them about staying safe in this virtual world. But we need to be reasonable. They need to balance screen time with spending face-to-face time, enjoying the outdoors, and actually participating in activities, instead of watching them. 
Wust how much screen time is too much screen time?
  t's all a matter of balance.
 It's not just the amount of time that matters, but also what you're doing with your device. Spending time on screens might be a problem if the child is using a device to escape from the things around them or if they are ignoring their family. Screens can make you feel more isolated from your surrounding. And when you're depressed, spending more time on screen might even make things worse. 

Screen time can be useful, to learn new things,  talk with family and friends, and enjoy innocent entertainment. Once you have a good balance of activities around screen time, it isn't bad. There is a lot of evidence that video games improve hand-eye coordination and sharpen the reaction time. 

We should balance our screen time with set activities. Every hour, take a walk outside for 10 min. Play with your dog. Hug your loved ones. Vacuum. Wash the dishes. Have the kids help us, and in doing so, we'll set an example of balance they can use for the rest of their lives. 

Screens are going to be a part of their life. We just need to teach them how to balance it with other thing
